Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Good pre-calc review if you've taken calculus in high school.
I rekindled my basic calculus rules and skills

I felt I gained a more in-depth depth understanding of functions and how they work, and learned many different ways to look at them. I learned how to take the derivative and approximate, maximize and minimize, graphing, and many other skills.
Derivatives.

Exactly what the course title says. Math 110 is the bridge between high school and college level mathematics. A solid way to review functions while being effectively introduced to concepts of calculus at the same time.
This course taught me a lot about derivatives and functions and how to apply that information.
updated basic math skills
Good practice problems and general notes in the textbook. Class notes could have been better rather than just random examples at times.
I felt that it was difficult to understanding things in class the way the professor explained it. I also felt like we didnt review specific material that we would be doing as much either.

Strengths: Course provided students with the tools and resources to fully understand the material, (textbook, ULA office hours, workshops)

Weaknesses: Lack of clarity on how to answer test questions. Answers seemed to be very specific in wording and this skill was rarely taught for questions.
I had a lot of strengths in the course however my top weakness was definitely the optimization word problems

Strength: Great teachers and awesome ULAs, office hours, ULA hours
Weaknesses: Some discrepancy between sections
This is a tough course for a first year student and I believe that nati wasnt able to educate us the information in a great way.

I think the strength was definitely in the resources provided. I attended office hours every week and they helped me greatly. The weakness was in the teaching. I felt as though the professors and their teaching was very confusing.

I would like to be able to work on the problems in the book in order to prepare for the tests, i.e., for example, get an answer sheet for all even numbers of problems in the book and then have the problem sets on all the odd numbers or vice versa.
yes if you need review on calc and pre-calc or if your calculus skills are not great.
I would only recommend it if you need the class for a major. Not fun at all and instructors are less than adequate if you don't get John Hall
Yes I would because I feel like it challenges you to think in different ways and will be very useful in the future.
It's more of a prerequisite type of course.
yes, it is a good course to take to learn calculus at a slower pace
Yes, I highly recommend this course to other students who want to learn calculus, and those who feel like they need a more indepth introduction to these concepts.
Yes I would reccomend the course to another student because I liked taking it and I also thought that the resources are very helpful.
yes, if you are interested in math and need to update your math skills this course is a great starting point.
